author: bridge-bot
content:
<thegaram33> the distinction between Common Core and rollup-geth cleared things up for me.

Common Core is a "rollup standard" that devs, wallets, etc. can use to figure out which EIPs/RIPs a rollup supports. I, as a rollup operator, can claim that my rollup is "CCv1 compliant" (and this is verifiable through audits, standard tests, etc.)

rollup-geth will implement the Common Core, and maybe many other EIPs and RIPs as well on an opt-in basis.

from a zk rollup perspective I'm not sure how useful rollup-geth will be. since the main complexity of our work is not implementing features on the node/sequencer, but implementing the zk verification part. and geth is not something that you can easily run on a zkVM.

author: bridge-bot
content: <n_0_0_0_0_0> What we aim to do is to write encapsulated/modular code and we plan to look into the different`L2-geth` implementations when designing "features";  this is to say, what you could get "for free" from `rollup-geth` is easier, or hopefully even cherry-pick or copy/paste,  "feature implementation"
